1111.content:
“WHAT THE HELL, ALAN!”

Alan grimaced and shifted the phone’s speaker away from his ear. “I told you, Vi,” he spoke, trying to keep his voice level. “I can’t do it. Tell ‘er I said sorry.”

“She paid you! It’s hard enough to go to college on minimum wage at best, and you’re just gonna take her money?” Alan’s brow furrowed deeper; despite his distance from the phone, his sister’s voice remained ear-piercingly shrill.

“I’m not a goddamn monster Violet, Christ. I’ll give her the fee back.” Alan fished his subway card out of his wallet and waved it across the turnstile’s sensor, looking around the station once or twice. Empty, thank God. “Maybe give her a nice card, too.” he joked, trying to lighten the mood. He winced at the strangled squeak the returned. That didn’t go over well.

“Ugh, she doesn’t need well wishes, you asshole!” Alan opened his mouth to protest but almost immediately thought better of it. “She needs a tutor!”

Alan’s frustration reached a zenith. “She needs Albert-goddamn-Einstein!” His shout echoed off the station’s pillars. “She’s unteachable, and she’s a moron! God knows how she got out of high school! God knows how she’s able to tie her shoes!”

Regret washed over him almost as soon as the words left his mouth. The other end of the phone was silent, save for a few scattered sobs.

“Fuck. You. Alan.” A heavy sniffle punctuated the condemnation. “I’d tell Hallie what you said, but it’d break her heart. Not that you’d understand what that’s like, you dickhead!”

“Violet, I didn’t mea—!” But his words only reached the beeps of the disconnect tone. The black call-screen faded, returning to the siblings’ equally vitriolic text chain. Alan slid a finger down the screen accidentally, scrolling past the harsh words and coming to rest on a picture of the argument’s subject — Hailie Morrison. Her smile was blinding.

https://external-preview.redd.it/ILmBg4B...

Alan guiltily stowed the phone in a jacket pocket and speed-walked to his line. He leaned against a nearby pillar, his thoughts drifting.

He definitely could’ve handled that better. When his sister had proposed that he ‘help an old highschool friend with her classes’ he didn’t think that she’d go to the wall for her. And he didn’t think that Hailie would need help with, well, all of her classes.

Alan kicked a littered can onto the subway track, frowning. It was his own fault, really. An indefinite tutor job for fifty bucks per session? He should’ve smelled something fishy. But he didn’t — probably because of the pretty face. God, Vi reeled him in with that pic, hook, line, and sinker.

Warning bells had gone off when she wasn’t at the library at 3. They rang louder when she rushed in, thirty minutes late, gushing apologies riddled with upspeak and ‘OMG’s. They rang loudest when her response to ‘What classes are you struggling with?’ was a shrug and: “I dunno, like, all of ‘em?”

He had kept his expression neutral when she gave him her latest tests to highlight her issues. Almost all of them were sub-forties, with one calamitously dropping down to single digits. An aside glance to look for the shame of atypicality was returned with a vacant stare, confirming his fears. These scores were normal; the Hailey Morrison standard.

A tinny ‘Please stand away from the platform’s edge’ buzzed out from the overhead speakers, interrupting his train of thought. Alan straightened up, frown still troubling his face, as the silver tube slowly ground to a halt.

He tried to let her down easily — and indirectly — but she was just too goddamned nice. He had mentioned how difficult his classes were going to be this semester, only to have her coo in surprise at how ‘mega-smart’ he had to be to take them and help her. When he had posed the problem that it would be hard to schedule future sessions around her job, she had assured him that ‘My hours ‘r flex— flexeb— I can move ‘em around ‘n stuff.’ And when their time was up and he was going to bite the bullet and tell her, she had pulled him into a warm, unexpected — and rather squishy — hug, and thanked him profusely, tears starting to pool in her eyes.

Hence the sister-proxy-cancellation. Hence the shouting match. Hence the likely-to-be-awkward family get-togethers that awaited him, most likely. He sullenly walked into the open doors of the train, absentmindedly noting that it was just as empty as the station. Weird.

Guilty thoughts swirled through his head as the train sped up, blurring the wall outside the window into a dun-colored smear. The next thing to catch his attention was...

11111.content:
Alan stared at his phone’s lock screen and the all-caps message his sister had seen fit to send. He chuckled nervously and looked circumspect at the empty subway car, half-expecting a black-clad squad of kidnappers to pop out. His sister’s text, though short and vulgar, read like a pseudo-threat, a promise of action rather than a prediction.

His muscles gradually relaxed as he thought the situation out. What could she do, anyways? Send embarrassing highschool pics to his friends? Spread salacious rumors? Tell Mom that he had been mean to her? He balked a bit at that; she did usually take Violet’s side, but he could probably reason past her initial burst of anger.

Alan was so caught up in the strategy of sororal warfare that he didn’t even catch his phone buzz with an alert.

He did catch the repeat alert two minutes later. It was Violet, of course. Curiously, the preview wasn’t a snippet of a vicious castigation, nor sinister promise. It merely read ‘Link Cannot be Previewed in iMessage’.

Alan pursed his lips at the tiny LCD screen. That was odd. Was it some documentary on the pitfalls of low-wage college education? A link to a study on the career prospects of college-drop-outs? He slid the banner to the left and unlocked the phone.

The thought of not clicking the link barely crossed his mind.

A white flash far brighter than the guttering subway lights illuminated the train car, driving Alan’s vision — and consciousness — into darkness.

~~~

Even before he opened his eyes, Alan could tell that something was wrong. The (presumable) sheets around him felt… odd, hugging his body in unfamiliar ways. Blood thumped in his ears. Oh God, was he paralyzed? Did he have a stroke?

An experimental wiggle of fingers and toes dispelled any immediate notion of immobility, but brought to light an unusual soreness mixed with numbness suffusing his body. Still, something was wrong. He wasn’t meant to be in a — unusually large, now that he thought about it — bed. He was meant to be on the subway, or in his dorm. Had he been under a fugue state?

Taking heart, Alan finally forced his eyes open. The view was elucidating, even through mysteriously blurry vision — this was no hospital, unless St Agnes had recently built a teenybopper wing. Faded pink wallpaper coated the walls of the room he was in, frequently interrupted by the occasional poster on the wall — their general subjects being boy bands both old and new, one particularly rumpled poster spiderwebbed by tape, save for a small quadrant with a signature in silver ink. Stuffed animals stood like wardens on various bits of furniture, save for a (pink, obviously) vanity that displayed an eclectic, if messy, collection of cut-out magazine pictures and beauty products.

A frown troubled his forehead. He could’ve fainted on the subway and been taken in by some good samaritan — and put in their teenage daughter’s room, by the look of it — or been kidnapped by some Misery-esque stalker. His heart quickened. First, find his phone. Then, investigation. Silence would be the key.

He quickly yanked the rosé blankets off of him… and any coherent plan vanished from his head. His vision was entirely occupied by two pale orbs, wrapped snugly in a balconette bra that seemed to be two sizes too small, forming a great valley of flesh that wobbled with the slightest movement. And wobble it did, for the two spheres were currently attached to the chest of near-hyperventilating Alan.

After a few seconds of panicked breathing, Alan managed to recover enough of his composure to obey his fight-or-flight instincts, scooting his rear to the head of the bed and scrabbling to a sitting position. But the weight of what seemed to be his prodigious chest followed him, bouncing with unnatural vigor.

His eyes unconsciously roamed over the unfamiliar sights — or, well, what he could see past the two protrusions. ‘Soft’ seemed to be the first word that described him: every inch of his body contained only the barest hint of muscle, enough to prevent cellulite, but insufficient to prevent ‘extra motion’. The boyshorts that he (apparently) seemed to be wearing cinched a ring into the downy flesh of his thighs, all the while supporting the unwitnessed yet very present mass behind him.

A quick pawing at the front of the underwear confirmed the sense of absence niggling at the back of his mind, as well as the second adjective: ‘Girly’. His toenails and fingernails were painted pink as the surrounding walls, his ankle accented by an pale pink heart on a silver anklet. The tickle of hair on his shoulder blades did nothing to disavow that notion.

At the discovery of the loss, an aftershock of fear and disgust struck Alan. In spite of his most fervent wishes, this could not be a dream. Everything was too… real. Even so, he impulsively shot a hand at his left arm, pinching the soft flesh harshly.

The involuntary squeak that escaped his lips sent chills down his back for reasons beyond its abnormality. It was… familiar. Too familiar.

His heart managed to find the strength to thump underneath its weighty ballast; Alan quickly swung his legs up and out of the bed, dread mounting in him. He winced as his feet hit the floor; a mixture of revulsion at the mild swing his hips brought to his gait, and dismay at his less-than-impressive height.

He half-stumbled over to the vanity, but halfway there, he already saw all he needed to see.

“Shit,” he breathed, in the squeaky, bubblegum-chewing, none-too-bright-sounding soprano of Hailie Morrison.

111113.content:
Hearing Hailie's sweetly bubbly voice swear was almost surreal in itself - beyond the fact that Alan was hearing it from the inside of Hailie's head. Something about the voice's pitch and Hailie's wide-eyed innocent face suggested that "shoot" was as close as the girl was likely to come to expletives. Not that this affected Alan's choice of vocabulary in the slightest.

"What the fuck..."

Hailie's face in the mirror moved at his command, the concerned and thoughtful expressions adding yet another layer of surreality as they were rendered on a face more closely associated with a blissfully uncomprehending lack of concern. A flash of extra concern ran across Hailie's - now Alan's, apparently - features as a horrifying thought entered Alan's racing mind.

"The current view that a favorable Brexit deal is unlikely makes Britain's moves towards tax and trade policies at odds with the United States all the more concerning as the nation risks finding itself more isolated from the international community that it anticipated."

*Whew*

Hailie's voice rendered the commentary rather less somber than Alan would have preferred, but at least the words had still come out.

"OK. I'm still me. Just, well, also not me." So maybe that last phrase had sounded very on-brand for Hailie, but in Alan's defense, it was at least accurate given the situation.

*KNOCK KNOCK KNOCK*

The sudden disturbance of Alan's thoughts made him - er, her - jump, setting in motion a series of jiggles that felt entirely wrong as Hailie's chest obeyed the laws of inertia.

"Hailie, sweetheart," the words and tone of voice from the other side of the door suggested that this was likely Mrs. Morrison, "are you awake? You don't want to be late for your tutoring appointment again like you were yesterday honey."

Vi hadn't canceled the appointment! Alan's mind shuffled through possibilities. There was no rational reason to expect it, but somehow he knew that if he was in Hailie's body, she must be in his. And Vi's text! That must have been what triggered this! Maybe he could convince Hailie to help him convince Vi that she needed to undo...

"Hailie? Sweetie?" The knocking was louder this time and the voice a bit more insistent.

Deciding that simple was best (and probably most in character) Alan went with a simple "I'm up!" in response.

"Oh good. You've got a couple of hours before you have to go, so don't take too long deciding on an outfit hon!"

On the other side of the door, footsteps retreated, leaving Alan alone again with his thoughts and with the need to get dressed presentably.

Despite being as disorganized as Hailie's brain, the room was at least clean, and what Alan had initially taken as faded pink wallpaper was, in reality, intentionally pastel. Searching through the room to find out where Hailie kept various bits of clothing turned out to be an interesting archaeological expedition. The discovery of a few books was initially surprising - until Alan noticed that they were the "Twilight" series. Still, she did at least read something, which was a start.

The space between the vanity and Hailie's wardrobe turned out to be home to a decently sized pile of what appeared to be academic award certificates. The incongruity piqued Alan's curiosity and he couldn't stop himself from looking closer.

"In recognition of achieving the most volunteer hours..."

The pile contained certificate after certificate thanking Hailie for her dedication to volunteering - at a food kitchen, at a nursing home, in the children's wing at the local hospital... None of the volunteer positions had been the sort to require much in the way of brains, but the cards interspersed with the awards made it clear that what Hailie gave was what people needed most - someone to talk with and someone to brighten their day.

*KNOCK KNOCK*

"Hailie, sweetie, you'll need to be ready soon if you want some breakfast."

Alan looked over at the clock. He'd lost a half-hour contemplating why Hailie never mentioned all her volunteering. The only answer he could think of was that she simply didn't think it was special - several cards had referenced Hailie saying that she didn't understand why just being nice to people was so much of a big deal.

"I'll be ready soon mom!"

The footsteps retreated once again and Alan focused his attention on getting dressed.

Unfortunately, Hailie only seemed to own clothing designed to highlight her chest. Then again, Alan thought as he looked into the mirror, struggling with Hailie's bra, Hailie's entire body was designed to highlight her chest. Setting on a pair of entirely too tight jeans and a similarly too-tight t-shirt that left none of his current femininity to the imagination (and had required entirely too much jiggling to get into), Alan took a deep breath and headed out of Hailie's room...

11111313.content:
The conversation swirled around Alan’s head as he tottered around the kitchen, cleaning up the dishes — as he was prompted to by Mrs. Morrison’s gentle stare of expectation. A palpable sense of remorse filled him; he definitely shouldn’t have been so hard on Hailie, even if she’d probably never hear a word of it.

‘There’s still no way I can give her the help she needs on my schedule,,’ he resolved to himself, drowning a puddle of syrup in a stream of warm water. ‘I’ll just throw some names around for her. Gareth’d appreciate her company, probably.’ He stowed the rinsed plate in the surprisingly large dishwasher, a satisfied smile curling his lips.

‘Well, that’ll come after Vi undoes this magic bullshit.’ he appended to his thoughts, wincing at the jostling inertia of the two most apparent consequences of the aforementioned ‘magic bullshit’. The shock at the discovery that, yes, magic was real had faded with his ventures through the anarchy that reigned over Hailie’s room; catching glimpses of the half-dressed bombshell mirroring his every action and expression in the vanity’s mirror was numbing, in a way.

Still, he had an appointment to keep; one that might actually be a ticket into a body that was less hyper-feminine. Alan scanned the room, searching for information that his body should already possess. The view from the window was a fairly benign suburb, maybe a bit richer than the norm. Hailey was thirty minutes late to her appointment, so, assuming that she left around threeish and the trip took around forty minutes — give or take a few minutes to find parking — then he should be in… Glendale!

Privately glowing with the satisfaction of a solved case, Alan looked around the room, once again, searching for a conspicuous hook or any such den for car-starters.

His impromptu search was interrupted by a forbearing “Hailie, sweetie,”. He swiveled his head owlishly to Mrs. Morrison, who wore the patient ‘bless-your-heart’ smile that all moms seemed to have.

“Your car is still in the shop, snookums,” she continued, wiping the waffle iron with a damp washcloth. “Daddy needs the other one for work, so you have to take the bus again.”

“Ah. Thanks.” Alan tried to smother the grimace threatening to appear on his face with the blank look that had worked so well earlier. “Whenzit coming?”

A little bit of long-suffering weariness shone out from Mrs. Morrison’s smile, mixed with a hint of slight concern. “Fifteen minutes, Hail-bale, right down the street. Same time as yesterday.”

Alan muttered a quick ‘Thanks,’ and resumed his search, this time for a bu—

“I put the pass in your bag, dear.”

A small blush heated Alan’s cheeks. It seemed that Mrs. Morrison had developed a preternatural sense of prediction for her daughter’s antics. He couldn’t tell what was more embarrassing: being treated like a kid again, or the fact that his fumbling bore a resemblance to Hailie’s own routine.

He stowed these insecurities to the back of his mind as he picked up and donned the hot pink clutch purse Mrs. Morrison had gestured to. If everything went according to his plan, he shouldn’t have to worry about his self-slash-Hailie’s-image for too much longer.

He briefly checked the purse’s contents as he walked to the front door, managing to produce the lackluster tests that he had been shown yesterday, a small makeup compact, and the promised bus pass, alongside various candy wrappers and loose change. Good enough. He opened the door, taking a deep breath…
“Did you remember your phone?”

Alan felt a familiar blush redden his face, as he mumbled a ‘No’ and scampered upstairs to fetch the pink-cased device and, as per another shouted reminder, a pastel-purple wallet.

Clawing through the mess of Hailie’s room took a good seven minutes, (thankfully) shortening his farewell with Mrs. Morrison to a hasty “Bye!” as he slammed the door behind him. After a few seconds of thought, he threw the door open and appended a hesitant “...Mom!”. You know,Just to keep up appearances.


~~~

Alan always prided himself on his punctuality. He made it a habit to show up five minutes early to any occasion at the very least, car or no car. As such, he had mastered the technique of the light jog and had the requisite muscles to show for it. The bus station was, what, a ten-minute walk away? He could make it in five.

And he probably could. For Hailie, however, it would be a long shot.

Alan was no idiot. He knew that Hailie wasn’t built for athletics — he hadn’t seen many female athletes sixty-one inches tall with two ballast bags stapled to their chests — but he had been a star on the track team! Surely he could eke out her hidden potential.

But whatever athleticism Halie possessed was stymied by Alan’s clothing choice. The vacuum-sealed jeans condensed any long strides he made into what could only be described as a high-impact mince, rocking his hips from side to side like an accelerated sensual pendulum.

The consequences of his gait extended well above waist level: Alan’s choice in clothing was facilitated by haste as well as modesty; he picked out a loose-ish one with a large band to avoid any boob-wrangling.

Right now, he was really regretting not putting on a sports bra, or at least something tighter; the loose one he had picked hardly restricted his chest at all, jostling it to the left, right, left, right, etc., heavy flesh painfully schlapping against his ribs with every step.

Alan managed to continue his jog for a full block before acknowledging the elephant in the room — or rather, ‘elephants in his shirt’ — and doing something to stop the extreme wobbling.

He held the twin mountains in his hand, which worked surprisingly well for a half block — before he was met with the offended gasp and gaze of an old lady walking her mini-schnauzer. Red-faced for what seemed to be the nth time that day, he released his death-grip on his tits, opting instead to endure the symphony of slaps another way.

The solution he settled on was as humiliatingly feminine as it was cartoonish. Either impuissant forearm stood sentry on either side of his flesh-balloons, wrists limped for simple convenience. If his next pivot-step was to the left, that respective arm would stifle the next imminent thwack into a less painful wobble. This process was mirrored and repeated on his — much to the joy of nearby gawkers — until he swished his way to the bus stop.

Riding the bus — which came about a minute later — was no better. The bus was packed to the brim; every single seat occupied by some morose passenger, leaving Alan to stare enviously at the rows of chairs as he clung weakly to a stanchion.

Alan spent the twenty-minute journey gazing morosely out the dirty window, trying not to notice the side eyes he received with every pothole. Some fiery part of him wanted to call them out, or at least flip them off, but what would that achieve? A few minutes of averted gazes, at best, and a forty-second section in ‘TOP PUBLIC FREAKOUTS OF OCTOBER,’ with fifty comments helpfully timestamping the ‘ditz with the tits’ at worst? Shit, Vi’d have his head for that.

It was a relief when his stop came but only in the psychological sense; his shoulders and ribs still duly throbbing with every step up the library’s stairs. A wan smile curled his lips as he glanced at the clock above the reference desk; he was ten minutes early.

The lady at the desk greeted the approaching footsteps with a picture-perfect customer service and, to Alan’s appreciation, unbroken eye-contact.

“How can I help you, miss?” she chirped, head tilted

“I’m looking to reserve study room B,” Alan said, only slightly put off by the appellation. “Underneath Al— Hailie?” He winced internally; the mistake and hasty correction sounded all-too-natural in Hailie’s voice.

The receptionist returned a jaunty nod and flipped through a nearby binder with a disarming amount of zeal. “Oh, you’re Hailie? You can just walk right in,” she cooed. “Your friend’s waiting for you.”

Alan could only nod numbly and stiffly march in the receptionist’s pointed direction. The lady seemed the type to giggle and simper at the mere thought of a coed study session, and Hailie certainly didn’t seem to be the type to have any guys as ‘friends’, so that left…

“Yo, Al,” drawled a very familiar voice from a very familiar person learning next to a door with a large ‘B’ on it.

“Let’s have a talk.” said Vi, as she half ushered, and half-frogmarched her brother into the study room.

111113133.content:
The air inside the room was tense; both Alan and Vi making concerted efforts to not look at one another. Alan dared a look at Vi: she still wore the same smirk she had a moment ago, but with a lot less confidence.

Everything else about her just seemed, well, normal. There were no glowing tattoos or green skin tone to hint at supernatural powers, just the same Violet, with the same dyed-purple hair she’d had since that goth phase that she never quite grew out of.

Vi cleared her throat, making Alan jump. “Man, it’s weird looking at you.”

“I… — You f— i-it’s weird for you?” The miasma of anger and confusion stewing inside him did nothing to help his articulation, sending his words tumbling out all at once.

“Yeah,” continued Vi, unperturbed. “You look like her, but you’re obviously, well, not. Your eyes are all dart-y, for one.”

A short, harsh bark of laughter escaped Alan’s lips. “Oh, I’m so god damned sorry, Violet. Next time, give me a few days’ notice; I’ll be sure to stare off into space to make you comfortable.”

Alan tried to channel all of his rage into a withering scowl, but by the looks of Violet’s confused frown, it’s not that effective. The quick look he snuck at Hailie’s cracked phone returned a sulky pout, confirming his suspicions.

“Jeez-us, someone woke up on the wrong side of the bed.” Vi frowned, tersely inspecting her fingernails. “You’re not doing yourself any favors.”

“Do you want me to thank you, for ripping me away from my life and putting me in Little Miss Du—”

“DON’T. START.” thundered Vi.

Alan wisely shut his mouth.

“Look, I’m not trying to — I ju—” Vi let out a deep sigh, combing fingers through her hair. “Let’s just start over again.”

Alan gave a hesitant nod, eyes edged with suspicion.

“Tempers flared last night. We both said, or...” She gestured vaguely at Alan. “... did things that we regret.”

“Is that supposed to be an apology?! Fine, I said some shit, but you hex me in response?”

“It’s a charm, asshole, and this is an explanation.” Vi shot back. “You’re making this way harder than it needs to be.”

“Fine,” said Alan as he attempted to find a comfortable place to cross his arms, ”Go on, then.”

“It — er, the charm, that is — is based on connections, bonds, relationships; whatever you wanna call them.” Vi laced her hands together demonstratively. “You and me are like this, cuz you’ve been nagging me all my life, and I’ve known Hailie since known Hailie since her two consecutive junior years."

“Charming,” Alan snorted. “Why didn’t you just make pals with her professors, and zap yourself into that oh-so-convenient position?”

“Because she’d know, dickhead! She can recognize that she’s not good at that nerd shit like you are; suddenly getting perfect scores in every subject’d tip her off that something’s up! And she, well, she wouldn’t like that.” Vi concluded, rather lamely.

The cutting remark perched on the edge of Alan’s tongue died and was replaced with genuine curiosity. “Is she okay with this, then?” He gestured vaguely to his figure.

Vi squirmed uncomfortably in her seat. “I, um, kinda told her that was your idea....” She blanched at Alan’s blackening expression. “You get to see what her classes are like to help her out and maybe a bit of your egghead lifestyle’ll rub off on her!”

Now, it was Alan’s turn to shout, or, rather, squeak loudly. “You turned me into a fucking exchange program?!”

“Look, you’re mad and I get that, but Hailie really, really, really really needs your help. I visit her at work and she’s all smiles, but she’s hurting, deep down. The girls tell me that she spends all of her breaks studying, but it’s just not helping.” She reached across the table and took Alan’s small hand in hers. “This is the only time I’ll ever admit it, but you’re smart as hell, Alan, and you’re not a complete piece of shit. I know you can help her so, please, for me, can you?”

Alan stared back at his sister, her face knitted into a supplicating pout he hadn’t seen since they were kids. The hard edge that he was cultivating slowly wore away, and he responded with...

“I’m really sorry Vi, but I can’t.”

“Why not?” Vi released his hand as her face set itself into hard lines.

“My schedule, my classwork—”

“Bullshit,” snarled Vi. “If you didn’t struggle with four APs and mock trial club during senior year, you’re not gonna break a sweat here.”

“W-well, I can’t take the time to meet her constantly,” Alan attempted. “I live on campus and this library—”

“— is a fifteen-minute subway ride away. And I’m a witch, not a Luddite, I know that Skype exists.”

For the second time that week, Alan's rage cresendoed and erupted spectacularly.

“Christ, can you not read between the fucking lines, Vi? Or do I have to say it: I DON’T WANT TO! Is that clear, or do you want me to write it down?!”

Vi stood up and Alan belatedly realized how tall she was.

“I can read between the lines better than you can, apparently,” she spat, stepping closer to Alan with every word. “You don’t want to teach her because you’re a shallow bastard who doesn’t give a shit about people other than himself!”

Alan opened his mouth to return a tirade of his own, but no sound came out. The lights in the room flickered and the blinds rattled as Vi smiled wickedly.

“Fine then. You say tutoring someone’ll waste your semester? I’ll gladly oblige you.” Her fingers twisted and though she didn’t touch him, Alan could tell that something had changed, like some rope he that he had been in had suddenly broken.

“Until Hailie Morrison passes her finals, get used to bras and panties, shortstuff,” she jeered, “And I like that exchange program idea of yours, so I’ll just…”

She closed her eyes and formed her lips into soundless, unfamiliar syllables, her hands dancing in the air like possessed spiders. Alan’s head flashed cold, as though doused with a bucket of ice. “... enforce it!”

Alan hurled soundless curses at her as she walked to the door, waving a cruel goodbye, “Have fun with your tutoring session, ‘Hailie’!”

Alan, to his credit, managed to hurl a “FUCK YOU!” after he regained use of his lilting soprano. As his anger waned, his current situation dawned on him in its entirety.

“Shit,” he moaned, burying his face into his matchstick arms. “I’m so fucked.”
111113133.title: Second Sibling Spat

1111131331.content:
The thing about deep, calming breaths is that they don't work nearly as well when all they really do is remind one of his or her situation - as Alan discovered thanks to the way his own calming breath mostly just reminded him of the tightness of Hailie's shirt.

Still, it helped enough to get him back into a mental space where he could consider his options. Running out to search for Vi didn't seem promising - she had a head start and her own car, which meant that finding her would likely amount to blind luck at best. Plus, Alan thought as he shook his head, still trying to clear the odd sensation of having just had ice water run in one ear and out the other, even if he did find Vi right now there was a nonzero chance that he'd only make things worse. And he definitely did not want to find out what "worse" might mean.

"OK Alan," he winced slightly at the girlish tone, "you can get through this. Make nice to Hailie, convince her to take the quarter off so she's not overwhelmed by my classes, and then pass her classes for her. That should defuse Vi..."

A knock on the door of the study room pulled Alan out of his reverie.

"Um, this is, like, the right study room, right?" His own head poked through the door with a quizzical expression that brightened into the sort of carefree and excited expression that would have been more at home on a small child receiving candy. "Oh good! I got the right one! I couldn't remember if Vi said room 'B' or room 'D' 'cause they kinda sound the same and then I got here and the rooms only went up to 'C' and I got a little confused until I thought that since there wasn't a room 'D' that meant it had to be room 'B' unless I had the wrong library but that wouldn't have made sense 'cause why would Vi be at the wrong library..."

"Um, yes... Good job..." Alan tried to blink away the surreality of hearing his own voice babble away with Hailie Morrison's characteristic cheerful babbling.

"I know, right?" Alan's former face positively radiated happiness as Hailie clapped once in emphasis before settling down at the study room table. "I'm super sorry I'm late and stuff, but, like, I had to take the bus 'cause I can't do the whole stick shift thingy and you know how buses are so never on time."

Hailie waved a hand in a manner so feminine that Alan winced a little at the thought of the damage she might do to his reputation over the course of the quarter.

"Yes, well, I'm sure we can work something out to let you borrow a less complicated car until we fix this..." The distracted nature of Alan's comment was clear even through Hailie's generally-slightly-detached vocal tones as he settled into the chair next to his former body. For just a moment, he studied his former body with a slight frown as it organized a few books on the table. "You're certainly taking this well..."

Hailie blinked at him. "Well, yeah? I can't change it so, like, what good would it do to be all worried about it?"

"That's..." Alan paused as he processed his surprise, "...a good point..." Thankfully, Hailie seemed not to take any insult from the way he obviously hadn't expected such a deeply coherent sentiment. "Anyway," Alan shook his head slightly, "since it seems like we're going to be like this for a while..."

"Vi said you were going to do my whole quarter for me!"

"Yes... Um... Well, you see, that means you're going to have to pretend to be me for a while and I'm going to have to pretend to be you, so I think maybe today I should start with..." Alan trailed off as the pink-cased iPhone on the desk in front of him pinged with the sound of an incoming text.

>> Remember to listen to your tutor, HAILIE. Alan is much smarter than you, after all. Well, maybe not yet...

The final clause of Vi's text dominated his attention to the point that Hailie's babbling went unnoticed until she tapped him on the shoulder, causing him to jump in his chair and her to giggle at the way he reached up to stop the resultant jiggling in his chest.

"Huh?"

"I said that since I'm, like, you or something, that means I'm the tutor and you hafta learn from me! Vi said it was some kinda experimental learning or something?"

"Experiential you mean?"

"Yeah! That thing! Anyway, she said I should teach you all about bein' me and that'd help me learn how ta be you? I kinda don't get it, but I usually don't get it, so that's, like, not really a big deal, ya know?" Alan couldn't suppress his nodding. "So. The first thing she said I gotta teach you is that you're Hailie Anne Morrison now."

For just a moment, Alan's head swam. It was as though every memory of anyone calling his name, every memory of him telling someone his name or writing his name down, was being played back at once and in one instant, each instance replacing the name 'Alan Michael James' with 'Hailie Anne Morrison'.

"Whoa..." Shaking his head, he looked up to see his former body glancing down at him with a slightly concerned expression.

"Are you OK Hailie?"

"I'm fine Alan. And you don't need to teach me that. I'm not going to forget that I'm Hailie. That's what everyone always... calls... me..." The former Alan trailed off what he'd just said sank in. He knew he'd only been in this body since this morning. He knew he used to be Alan whatever-his-middle-name-was James. But when he thought about his name it was Hailie Anne Morrison that came instantly and instinctively to mind.

No! This was too much! He was going to fight this! Vi couldn't just make him respond to...

"Hailie?"

"Yes?" He was already looking up at his former body before he consciously realized that he'd snapped to attention in response to the name Hailie. "Damnit!"

His former body giggled again.

"Vi said you'd prob'ly be a little upset, but, like, trust me, it'd be way bad if you accidentally forgot you were Hailie, right?" The newly christened Hailie nodded grudgingly. "'Kay! So, um, I know you gotta work tonight, but I s'pose we can spend a little bit more time studyin'... I think I should teach you more about..."
1111131331.title: Hailie gets her new tutor...

choices: The lesson is interrupted by mind-magic.
11111313312.content:
Hailie stared up at his puppeteered former body with his heart hammering in terror. Time seemed to slow — though it probably wasn’t necessary, with the way that Alan was dithering.

She took his name, for Chrissake! Sure, being called Hailie just felt right, but that fact, er, feeling alone was freaky. Plus, who knows what else she’d take? The implications chilled him to his core. Alan could disassemble him, piece by piece, bit by mental bit, leaving him no better than the original, some kind of Ditz of Theseus.

No. He wouldn’t let that happen. Hailie surged up with all the strength that his soft legs afforded him, clamping a hand over Alan’s mouth…

Ow. Did his chest, uh, hit something? And why did his feet feel wet?

The two of them looked down at the spilled water bottle and its contents pooling on the floor, Hailie’s hand still on Alan’s mouth. It took a few seconds for both of them to take in the damage, but when they did, both seamlessly transitioned into damage-control mode.

“Uh, sorry, Alan, I didn’t mean to — ohgodit’salloveryourpantsimsosorry”

“Oopsies, I def’ntly shouldn’t ‘a left the bottle there. Are you, like, hurt at all, Hailie?”

Hailie almost instinctively retreated from his copy’s wide (obviously practiced) puppy-dog eyes and shockingly large outstretched arms — the nth reminder today that he was just small now.

“I— I’m all good,” Hailie assured, gently pushing Alan away to avoid the alien sensation of being hugged by one’s own body. “Just… could you go get some paper towels?” He gestured vaguely at Alan’s pants. “And you, uh should dry that off before you sit in anything. Might ruin the chair.”

Alan’s eyes lit up with joy at the prospect of something to do to help, and just as quickly fell into abject despair at the thought of inconveniencing library staff. It took a few seconds for the direct request to register, but once it did, she shot right up to her feet.

“Gotcha, Hale-bale.” Hailie masked his nauseous expression as Alan tittered in delight. “Ooh, that feels mega-weird to say.”

Hailie watched his former body flounce out of the room, elbows tucked tight to the ribs and wrists limped in a chillingly familiar display. He groaned again: maybe he could tell his friends that he got lead poisoning or something — at least it’d be easier to explain.

Hailie shook his head — that wasn’t important. What was important was —

Alan’s head poked its way through the ajar door. “Uh, do ya, like, know where the bathroom is?”

“... I think there’s one on the second floor. Take a left at the top of the staircase.”

Alan grinned and shot a thumbs up before once again taking her leave. Hailie watched her go, inchoate thought forming in the back of his head. Was he forgetting something…?

Oh god

He ran to the door and hissed as loudly as was socially acceptable. “The guy’s bathroom, Alan!”

Alan, in response, shouted “‘Kay!”, heedless of standard librarial conduct. Before he shut the door, Hailie could spy a matronly librarian making her way over to the cheery Alan, mouth set in a stern line.

He closed the door with a sigh. Not much he could do about that. Or, really, anything Hailie wanted to do in his body. He couldn’t really—

Hailie pinched the bridge of his borrowed button nose. Don’t panic. Just think.

He strode over to Alan’s side of the table, running his hand over his old knapsack half-affectionately. Unless Alan packed the whole thing with pink cupcakes and confetti, there should be…

Success! Hailie pulled out a yellow legal pad, the corners dogeared from months of eager use. There were only a few unscored pages left, but they would do.

The word ‘flowchart’ was the quickest way to Hailie’s heart that one could find. Organizing his thoughts, hopes, and fears into list form was a great comfort to his rigid logos-oriented brain. And sometimes just free association brought a degree of calm, writing down things that instinctively registered as ‘bad’ and ‘good’ into an ersatz pros and cons list.

He mostly kept this organization to himself, though. Girlfriends didn’t react well when you showed them a cost/benefit analysis of your relationship thus far, and they got more than a bit tetchy when they realized that the whole thing was leading into a break-up.

Hailie, smiling for the first time in a long while, began with a perfect ellipsis of a start-point, almost humming with delight as he drew a wonderfully straight line connecting to a now-unknown process step.

It was ritual-like for the stodgy Alan, the kind of relaxation that other people got with a bucket of ice-cream, a spoon, and an overcrowded Netflix queue. He’d never boast about it (in public), but he prided himself on having a productive, logical means of stress relief.

Alan wrote in the terminal bubble, “Vi turns me into Alan,” before glowering at the paper and crossing out ‘Alan’ in favor of ‘Hailie’, then, with a pained expression of concession on his pretty face, crossed out the name and wrote ‘Alan’ below the scribbles.

Horribly intrusive mind-magic aside, it was better for instinctive recognition.

The bubble was then connected to ‘I get pissed at Vi’. A mistake, to be sure, but it had happened.

After putting pen to pink lips, he connected it to ‘Vi establishes ‘exchange program’, resisting the puerile urge to include a frowny face.

Then, frowning for real as he moved his pen, he wrote ‘Alan trades names’ in the fourth bubble. Yup. That was what happened. Hailie allowed himself ten seconds to let the wave of existential dread wash over him, then shook it off as best he could with a small whirlwind of copper hair.

The past was the past. Time for plans.

He didn’t even bother putting ‘Find Vi’ as an option, despite the consideration he gave it before. Sure, if he begged, or considering the wide-eyed innocence of Alan, simply asked, he’d probably get a cheerily-delivered exact location of the gothy girl. But twenty-odd years and the very strange last twenty minutes didn’t leave him feeling safe and secure about the lengths she’d go if he pushed the wrong sister-button.

Sighing, he put the option he’d decided upon before in a potential path. ‘Convince Alan to drop classes’. That was a normal thing, right? His friends — no, more importantly, his record wouldn’t be marred by one teensy tiny semester off, right? There wouldn’t —

Hailie stopped his catastrophizing with a small slap to a soft cheek, and a deep, diaphragm-centred breath (to avoid any shirt-stretching). Panicking was bad.

And maybe it wasn’t all bad. Maybe he could liiiightly push Alan into taking the time to volunteer in the place of classes, given that she apparently had an affinity for the act. He’d just have to try to frame it in a way that would absolutely not get back to Vi.

Which, given his two-hours-total with Alan, and one whole morning to learn how other people treated her, seemed outright goddamn impossible. Persuading Alan to drop the semester was the easy part — she was, for lack of a better word, dumb; dumb people don’t like doing hard things, explain to Alan in no uncertain terms that the classes were hard, bish bash bosh — but the chatterbox would probably gush effusively to Vi about how easy things were now that she didn’t have classes if his sis ever decided to check-in. And, judging from Vi’s her near-mother-hen tendencies, she’d probably do so immediately.

And who knows what Vi would do.

He added an annotation to the path, ‘Too risky’.

That left, as far as Hailie could see, one option. He’d have to, ugh, teach her. Not the innate understanding he had of the entire curriculum, just, well, the basics. How to take notes, maybe some formulas for the maths-core he took — God, why had he opted for the advanced class?~ And then it’d be up to Hailie to cobble together the stuff from her loopy-handwritten notes, write some essays, do the math problems...

Well, it would be a lot of work, but Hailie’s classes were pretty easy. A basic math class, some English Lit I, some History and… well, he’d need to check out the rest. Still, he’d had more plates in the air before. He could do this.

Hailie wrote, ‘Teach Alan’ and added a little sketch of a thumbs up next to the bubble, before stowing the flowchart in a pocket with a grunt of frustration. Why did they have to make the things so damn small?!

Still, he’d need to distract Alan from doing that ice-water-trade-whatever thing. He needed to lead the conversation, not just blithely be swept along into Alan’s rhythm.

He needed to, against all odds, teach the airhead.

Hailie sourly noted the irony as he started sketching out the basics of a lesson plan.

111113133123.content:
Hailie bounced a denim-clad leg under the table, drumming a pink nail of the table for added effect. Initially, he had sped-wrote the plan, establishing vague concepts that he’d flesh out on the fly, but Alan was taking a loooong time.

Like, twenty-minutes-total-long.

Long enough for him to refine his plan with a dizzying array of talking points and a small amount of (web-searched) math problems for practice, so he wasn’t especially complaining.

When Alan knocked on the door, Hailie had mentally prepared for it enough to nod politely at his old body, rather than start at the surprise and start another symphony of chest-sloshing.

“Hey, Al—,” He frowned at the automatic response, but managed to plaster the same placid smile back on and kept chugging on; “Hey, Alan, I just thought we cou—”

“Ohmigawd, Hailie, I’m so sorry, cuz’ first I went to the bathroom and then they didn’t have paper towels so I kinda haddta hold my leg up like this —” This time Hailie did start as Alan thwacked a leg onto the unstable table — “to the air-blow-dry-thingie, which took a looong time, and then when I got out, there was this sweet ol’ lady trying to get something on a shelf, so I got the thingie and she said ‘Oh you sweet young man’, an’ I laughed a little at that, then haddta explain, like, why I laughed, but not, like, the real reason, cuz —”

“Alright, Alan,” interrupted Hailie, beatific smile on his face. Apparently, entering the room late with a meandering explanation seemed a Hailie Morrison staple. Put it down on the lists of mistakes he would never make. “I thought I’d just go over some Alan basics before we wrapped up.”

The awfully contrite expression on Alan’s face slid into one of unabashed confusion. “But, like, I thought I was the tutor?”

Hailie had fielded this question five times in his head. “True — the experiential learning and all that —” Alan nodded sagely “— but you need to learn what to do before you can teach it, yes?”

“Yeah, I guess, but —”

“Good!” Best to keep her from ditz-ing herself out of a logical conclusion. “We’ll start off with note-taking. I like to have a memorized list of mnemonics, er,” The unabashed confusion was back. “I like to… remember things in a special way. For example, if the teacher keeps repeating a certain phrase — let’s say, um, in World History, they keep saying that the causes of World War One were alliances, militarization, nationalism, and imperialism, we just need to make an anagram…” The same look. “We… just need to, um, move the letters around and we get M.A.I.N.”

He went on like this for thirty more minutes, Alan (surprisingly) rapt with attention, scribbling down notes in messy, looped-letter handwriting. It surprised even Hailie that, well, it felt kinda good! Sure, he didn’t exactly command authority with sixty-two inches of height and a voice that sounded like it was promoting a new lip gloss but having someone interested in what he had to say was, well, nice.

He was about to move on to the topic of note-taking, maybe gently pointing to Alan’s notes as an example of what not to do when the subject at hand cut in with a coo that sounded like it should be two octaves higher.

“Wow,” breathed Alan. “Like, this is so cool. I wish I could do this kinda thing for my job.”

It was like a small pinch, a brief moment of electric heat in his head that sent Hailie a-wobbling for a second. A hot flash? Was Alan old enough to get hotflashes? Anyways, it was distracting enough to necessitate a small peek down at his yellow-papered lesson plan, underneath the -NOTES- section.

Hm. That was odd. He couldn’t read the handwriting. Well, sure, he could still read the letters, but, uh, they clearly weren’t words. What did ‘shrt stncs’ and ‘abbr.’ mean? He must have been writing too fast near the end. No matter, he could work from memory.

“So, Alan, when you’re taking notes, you, uh, need to write down what they say.” That didn’t seem right. Well, it was right, but something was... wrong. Hailie combed his mind for a few seconds before snapping to with a chastened smile. “Sorry. That is to say, you need to write what they say, but not really.”

Alan let out a too-petulant grunt of frustration and looked down at the plan. Actually, now that he looked at it, the same not-words were everywhere. A sheepish chuckle (that sounded more like a giggle) escaped his lips as he turned to Alan, tucking a strand of fiery hair behind an ear. “Sorry, uh, again. I j— I seem to have written this incorrectly.”

“Ooh, lemme see,” burbled Alan, taking the yellow sheet of paper before he could tell her not to. Her eyes scanned the paper before turning to Hailie once more, face twisted into the same vague bewilderment. This time, it was a deserved bewilderment: how could he write so much nonsense?

“Uh, it totally makes sense to me.” The blood ran cold in Hailie’s veins. “It’s, like, the same thing you said earlier about the anemomnic thingy.”

“Mnemonic,” Hailie automatically responded, despite his utter lack of recollection of the definition.

“Yeah, that’s what I said! You just hafta, write in smaller words — like small enough so that they aren’t words! See, you wrote here that your brain just zwoops in the meanin’ if there aren’t any vowels, like, uh, P-L-S, an’ S-R-S!”

“Yeah, that makes sense,” mumbled Hailie, his head chin-down on the table’s cold wood.

~~~


The rest of the tutoring session was mercifully brief, but followed the same humiliating routine: Alan cheerfully explaining all of Hailie’s written concepts back to him in a mess of upspeak and ‘like’s.

He was able to pass his numb shock off as a dizzy spell and wave off all of Alan’s concerned efforts to get him ‘like, anything to eat,’ by citing the study room’s ‘NO FOOD OR DRINK’ sign.

He realized specifically why it had happened on the bus ride home, and couldn’t help but think about that magic was a bitch. Weren’t spells or charms or whatever supposed to have a consistent verbal component? Shouldn’t Alan have had to look him in the eye, and say ‘I teach you something something something?!’

No. Apparently not. Apparently, magic only had to interpret any of Alan’s vague ‘I want’ statements as absolute commands, like some asshole genie out of some stupid tropey cautionary tale.

He tried continuing his existing flowchart to destress and sort things out, but it didn’t help at all. The first five minutes of the attempt were spent doodling a flower-studded box to put the next step in, and the next six involved hi nibbling on the pen’s plunge like some secretary pinup model while thinking of what to put down, and the ensuing three were wasted on adjusting the box’s area after he had underestimated his handwriting’s size.

It took work now, which, coupled with distinct memories of accomplishing the same amount of work in less than half the time, just made him feel like complete and utter shit.

He didn’t even produce a good option. ‘Don’t meet up with Alan,’ written in a loopy, girly font. It’s not like it was even an option. If he decided to welch on a meeting, Vi would be on him like white on rice, and if she wasn’t vengeful, she’d be smug, which almost seemed worse.

The walk back to Alan’s house was better than the run to the bus — no urgency means no running means a massive reduction in chest-rebounding — but Hailie’s feet dragged the whole way back.
111113133123.title: Tutor Talent Trade-off

It's a pseudo-sexual modelling job. Eugh.
It's stripping. Of course it's stripping.
1111131331233.content:
It was another nail in the already-sealed coffin when, in front of the house, was a black minivan with a slightly chipped paint job. Hailie glumly concluded that it must be Alan’s dad — though all the peeling Bay Area beach passes didn’t seem especially paternal.

He opened the large oak door without as much as a ‘Hello’ and entered to a conversation that Alan’s mom was apparently having.

“— house is beautiful, Mrs. Morrison.” rang an unfamiliar female voice.

“Yeah, I don’t think they have this many paintings at the museum.” added another girl, her voice supersaturated with vocal fry.

“Kimmy!” scolded a third.

“It’s quite alright, dear.” Mrs. Morrison laughed, “I’m just glad that Hailie’s made such wonderful friends at — oh, speaking of, I believe she’s home now.”

“Get in here, girlfriend!” yelled ‘Kimmy’, and Hailie cringed in response. These were apparently his — er, Alan’s friends. Were they going clubbing? Did community-college girls go clubbing on Wednesday nights?

His mind racing to think of excuses — could he say that he was on his period or would they know? — he walked into the bustling living room, where he was greeted by a tanned, leggy blonde’s cool wave; a gothy-looking brunette’s sharp nod of acknowledgment; and a pear-shaped Asian girl — who still had three inches on him, Hailie bitterly noted — jumped up and encircled him in a tight hug.

“So, how was your date?” —Kimmy, he thought — mischievously whispered into his ear.

“Ther— It wasn’t —” Hailie’s stammering, once again, was eerily in character as the girl sat down with a giggle.

“What did you say, Kim?” shot the goth girl, her voice edged with suspicion.

“It was just a joke, Judy, relax!”

“Don’t tell me to relax, you—”

The potential-catfight was interrupted by another laugh from Mrs. Morrison, who gave the girls another practiced affectionate smile. “You remind me of my girlfriends back in college,” she sighed wistfully.

“That’s lovely to hear,” said the blonde with her own serene smile to match, “We’re pretty tight knit at… our job, but Hailie’s the glue that keeps us all together.” Another smile, this time aimed at Hailie, who returned a shaky one. Job friends? This was new information.

“Oh, you girls are so sweet,” cooed Mrs. Morrison. “Meeting at a grocery store of all places!”

At that remark, Judy and Kimmy exchanged a meaningful look that was then aimed at Hailie. The blonde didn’t seem to be as waylaid at the quarrelsome two, though, and brushed a lock of hair behind her ear before continuing: “Yeah, retail brings the unlikeliest of sorts together.”

Hailie’s silent-listener role seemed to be over as Alan’s mom turned to him and said, “Well, dear, it’s time to get changed.”

“What?” Were moms supposed to encourage their daughter’s parties, or was that a rich-parent thing?

Mrs. Morrison gave him a ‘come-on-dear’ look as Kimmy giggled. “Your job, dear. Remember yesterday? You talked for ages about carpooling.”

Alan put a hand to his cheek in fake realization to maybe recover some dignity. Alan did say something about a job. “Oh, um, yeah! I’ll just, go… and get changed.” Which grocery store did Alan work at? The one with the green apron or —

“glk"

His unsteady totter for the stairs was interrupted by a Judy-snagged shirt. “Hail, uh, forgot her uniform at work.”

By this time, Hailie could tell that something was up. Something that these girls — or, more likely, Alan — wanted to keep hidden. So, in an attempt to not ruin the complex web of confidentiality that he was apparently caught in, he did what the original owner of this body did best: play dumb.

“Oh yeah, that’s right!” he faux-exclaimed, and judging by the thumbs up that Kimmy surreptitiously gave him, that was the right response.

“Yeah, we should, uh, get going n’ stuff,” said Kimmy, driving Hailie by the hips towards the door, waving the other girls with her. “It was really nice to meet you, Mrs. Morrison!”

“You too, Kimmy, Judy, Rebecca! Feel free to come back anytime!”

“Thanks!” exclaimed all three girls as they went out the door.

Kimmy continued shoving Hailie all the way to the minivan, where he was packed into the backseat alongside the bubbly girl. Judy took the passenger seat, and ‘Rebecca’, the driver’s.

Silence prevailed in the car until Kimmy turned to Hailie with a serious expression that looked plain wrong on the girl.

You know, Hail, you really should tell her.”

Judy snorted from the front seat. “No she shouldn’t.”

Kimmy bristled once more at the dark-makeupped girl. “And why not?!”

“Kim, if you could see your thirteen-year-old self, would you tell her tha—”

“She’d think it was badass.”

Hailie could practically hear Judy’s eyeroll. “Fine then; would you tell your mom back then what your dream job was?”

Kimmy deflated. “I guess not…”

The keys turned in the ignition, bringing the car to life with a rumble that made everyone but the blonde jump. “It’s fair for Hailie to not want to tell her mom, but—” She turned back to level a look of grave importance at Hailie, “— you should tell her eventually. Honesty is important.”

“A-alright.” For one femtosecond, Hailie weighed the benefits of telling them that he was actually the tutor — and see how they liked that honesty — but getting Hailie locked up in an insane asylum probably wouldn’t get him any points with Vi or Alan.

Rachel reaches over and takes you by the hand, "Come on Missy! "Silly girl," she laughs, "I don't know without measuring you, but I'd guess you're about 6 feet of adorable."

Well, at least you haven't changed, even if everyone else is treating you weird. It's a partial relief anyway.

And now that Rachel's here, you can't even really force yourself to use your old names without your new nanny thinking something was weird. Lovely.

Rachel sits down next to your sister and motions for you to sit down too. As you sit down, Rachel starts up a conversation with with your sister.

"Hi! I'm Rachel, you must be Michael," Rachel brushes some stray hair out of her face and smiles brightly at your sister. "I found your sister after she wandered off and your mother asked me to help you look after her. I'm really glad I said yes." Rachel blushes slightly as she says the last sentence and you realise that Rachel's flirting with your sister. Wonderful.

Rachel handles the interruption surprisingly well and lets the two of you retreat to the other side of the tram car while she stays put.

You remember that only moments ago you were wondering what she looked like beneath her tank top, but now that doesn't seem important.

Your sister is looking equally surprised, but is now stealing glances back at Rachel with obvious interest. You realise that whatever's going on, it works regardless of whether it's your or your sister making the wish.

A sudden idea seizes you and you try to wish that your sister would think of Rachel the way a seven-year-old girl would.

15222.content:
Are you alright? You hear a muddled voice call out to you. This day has been a busy one, to say the least. Another day of working yourself to the bone, you were desperate to get home and into a comfy bed. But you got out later than usual, forgetting that your usual train didn't run so late. And so you took a chance on this train in this lesser known station. Never set foot in it until today, and while you otherwise might have been worried about the unfamilair territory, that ended quickly once you took a seat. And then started to lay down. And then closed your eyes.

Hello? Please, wake up! The voice was getting clearer now, and you could feel someone poking your back repeatedly. A nice, peaceful nap interrupted by some well-intentioned but annoying individual. But now paying attention to the sensations hitting your body, you feel one arm is very numb. You must have slept on a nerve or pinched it somehow. And then you get your face off of the seat and realize your left arm and leg were both hanging off the side of the seat this whole time. You could've been easily confused for a passed-out drunk in this position! But finally you take the opportunity to sit up and stretch.

"Oh, phew! I was worried you fainted or something." Turning to your left you see a young woman with green hair, probably in her twenties. She's dressed in an orange tracksuit and black shorts. "Huh, now that I got a better look at you, you don't look like you're from around here. Hmm..." She pulled out a red device and held it in front of you. A new phone, maybe? Nah, too wide... "Wow, you're from so far away! Cool!" You had to admit, after being forcefully woken up, this one-sided conversation was starting to get on your nerves...how would she even know where you're from? The girl definitely didn't notice the look on your face, though. "It's weird to see you all by yourself, too...is your Trainer with you?"

A personal trainer? Were you being confused for some famous athlete, maybe? You finally decided to speak up. "Listen, I-"

"Whoops! I forgot it was pointless to ask, sorry!" She says dismissively. You're almost in shock at her response. That was pretty rude! "Welp, just in case, let me try...THIS!" With swift movements, the girl grabs something from her pocket and throws it- directly at you!

"OW! What the-?!" You're distracted by the pain for a second and don't see what the object was. You vigorously rub the side of your head while glaring at the girl, unaware that your previously short hair began growing and making its way to your shoulders.

"Okay, so you're not wild. My bad. Your cry sounded pretty cute, though!" The girl sheepishly grins as the train grinds to a halt. "Oh, there's my stop. Nice meeting you!" And as quickly as you had met this girl, she vanished.

...what the hell just happened?
